ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I would love more time with Mark, Marlyse, and Richard out in the field--but I realize they were stretched thin as it was.

The work is back-loaded--the class starts up slowly and then you will get slammed at the end. Even though my group kept up with the scheduled work, crunch time was extremely unpleasant. I recommend that the instructor's get students going more immediately on data collection and tell them RIGHT AWAY that it's one line per tree when you're entering data in excel. We asked several times for advice on how to organize a spreadsheet, and we were told to wait until the lecture on the topic, when all someone had to say to us was "one line per tree." students should get to see a sample spreadsheet from years past before starting. if you haven't been on forest crew or done timber cruises before, it's doubtful you'd know what to do without that kind of support.
This is the best class I have taken ever.
Marlyse was a fantastic TF--super knowledgeable and dedicated, and always gave us a huge amount of her time.
4. The workload was heavier, but this is to be expected because it is a 6 credit course. But, I did do more than your average 6-credits worth of work.

Spending a lot of time in the field is valuable, but spending a lot of time in the car is not. There are good reasons why the work was done up near Yale Myers, but the class would have been less of a burden time-wise if a less distant site was involved.Field trips were good, worthwhile, and enjoyable, but the amount of time blocked out was often much greater than the content. I would suggest combining more than one of them into one day, which would be easy) to free up another Friday, or having another overnight to Yale Myers etc to free up multiple Fridays/Saturdays. This would be just as effective and be more mindful of students' time.

A whole weekend is dedicated in the beginning to touring all of the properties, as a class. This was a HUGE waste of time. We could easily have made it a day trip, with the teams splitting up and later reporting to others what the other properties were like

Time in the forest and the requirements to analyze all sorts of things--including soils and hydrology, for example, which I'm not particularly interested in. Demanding GIS. Though thank God we had a GIS guru on our team--without that, it would have been challenging to deliver all of the maps needed.I loved my larger team, and I think that future courses should really evaluate the strength/weakness of having large teams (ours was a five-person team) versus small teams (2-3 people). I do fear that the smaller teams had a huge burden especially given that they may not have had expertise in all of the areas.
The ability to take what we are learning in class and apply it in a real situation, working with a real client.

great field trips. great sense of accomplishment. great to get out into the field with my group and sample. i learned a lot about the forest by being in it for ~8 hours a week (and often more) during sampling season.
Everything
Its practical nature.

Synthesizing a lot of my work experience and coursework so far into a large project. Learning about Connecticut. Understanding the steps of a management plan from start to finish. Mark, Marlyse, and Richard's help and encouragement.

1. Dr. Ashton is a demanding and yet wonderful teacher.2. This course forces you to truly synthesize- physical sciences, GIS, social assessments, presentation skills, team work and desktop publishing. You finish by producing a professional-grade product.3. The mix of classroom time and field time is perfect.4. Professor Ashton does a nice job of blending demanding deadlines with an understanding that grad school life is hectic.
The set of skills we learned.

Seeing a large and complex project through -- from start to finish -- was very rewarding. Mark Ashton is a terrific teacher. Beyond his knowledge of applied ecology, he clearly cares deeply about students. He worked harder than any of us to ensure we were equipped for success. Richard and Marlyse were a great resource and always available to answer questions, head into the field, or read through drafts.

I had the opportunity to work with a client to develop a management plan from scratch. I learnt a lot of valuable skills which will go a long way in helping me in my future career. I also got the chance to in a team of 4 students integrate other courses, such as Stand Dynamics, Silviculture and Sampling I had taken at the school in previous semesters to actually apply them to a real life problem. I got the chance to learn a bit about soils, hydrology, social assessments and GIS which I had very little knowledge about.
The breadth of subject matter it covered, and the real world application of the work and analysis.

Hard choice. The professor - but the TA and Richard, forest manager, were also really important to the success of the class. We were really happy with our projects this year. My teammate was fantastic.
we learned a lot in the end, and were forced to get better at GIS and excel, which are necessary evils

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Ashton's lectures were a bit loose this semester. I would recommend taking out the stakeholder assessment, or really just condensing it to a 60-minute lecture. Most of it was common sense. There were one or two other lectures that felt the same--I didn't get most of the value this semester from the lectures, but rather field trips, our biophysical inventory, my internet and academic research, and time analyzing our data.I think that Mark and the TA need to do a MUCH BETTER job on the lecture on crunching data. We had asked for guidance, received none, and then already started inputting data into our own forms, only to discover weeks later that we'd done it incorrectly, an Excel file that was a template already existed (and hadn't been pointed out to us). Furthermore, I think there are some tools that we might be able to use to simplify data crunching. These templates should be updated in advance of the course, any kinks should be worked out, and they should be presented to the course in advance of the first day of data collection done by independent teams. Furthermore, the lecture Marlyse gave on the side about crunching data in the Excel and on Pivot tables was heavily attended by nearly every member of the class, on a Sunday. Rather than make it an add-on, and the TA's responsibility, Mark should simply do this as one of his lectures.
the timeline (discussed above).
Nothing
Nothing--it is well organized and a great course.
Communication between instructor and students. E-mailing one day prior can be a little nerve-racking.
We should get pizza like the 5 oclock class.....jk

1. The workshop on forest inventory analysis needs improvement and it would be nice to explicitly state the best way to enter forest data and to do so early on in the course.2. Many landowners like wildlife and birds- it would be nice to have a guest lecture/field tour by a wildlife biologist who could also explain an effective way to talk/analyze more coherently about wildlife.
A budget should be set aside for this class like for other classes to aid students with things like transportation, food etc. as there are a lot of back and forth traveling involved.Oh

There's a good reason why we cover such a breadth of material, but it often felt like we got only a cursory overview of it, and then we were expected to produce a competent product with little to go on. I'm not sure how to fix this - I understand and support the need to be a self-starter in this regard, but we too often felt like we had no idea which was to go with something, necessitating perhaps too many or unnecesessary questions for the prof and TAs.

The GIS lecture could be improved (maybe have it in a computer lab?).The deadlines could be a little bit tighter at the beginning of the semester (basic introduction to property, location, history, without the deed survey, could all be due after week 1 or 2 - to get teams started?)

mark is overworked, and the lectures seemed to suffer a bit. it didn't really seem like we learned too much in class, although the classes are generally fun. rather, he would touch on what we were supposed to learn, then it would be a bit of "trial by fire" out in the field. i suppose he intends it to be that way a bit. mark shines out in the field, not on power-point.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Great--particularly one-on-one. Not as good in big class sections. Maybe some of these lectures could be devoted to hour-long sessions in small groups with Mark and/or the TA, rather than big group lectures.
The instructor and TA were extremely willing to make themselves available and put in extensive time above and beyond normal to ensure that they were able to support the students and answer questions.
great
Amazing
Absolutely amazing---they devoted a huge amount of time and effort to helping us.
Very available and helpful.
Available and excellent help all around.

Professor Ashton is perhaps the most dedicated FES faculty- he is very available and when we needed help, he was there to offer it.Marlyse also did an excellent job as a TA. She helped on the technical issues ( eg InDesign and Excel) and also offered much qualitative advice.Richard was always available for help and also has a quick turnaround time on comments- much appreciated.
Excellent, amazing!
Already answered this, but Mark/Marlyse/Richard went above-and-beyond. They were always available and very helpful.
The instructor and TA must be commended for all their support and hard work all through the course.
excellent.

Unrivaled - It's hard to believe how much time Mark Ashton puts into this class. Marlyse and Richard sent very helpful comments on our plan drafts on very short notice. Mark made himself available whenever needed, and worked with our drafts in a constant rotation.
very available and helpful

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Great preparation for the spring rapid assessment in the tropics course, I'd imagine.
This course is a capstone for the MEM curriculum. More importantly, though, the course offered direct skills that I will be utilizing professioanlly when I graduate.
Perfect
This course is the perfect capstone for an MEM interested in land conservation

This course is a culminating class for me in the MF program. I think it should be considered a capstone course for the MF.It allowed me to synthesize lots of material and made me draw on every class I have thus far taken at FES.

My career objective is to work as a natural resource manager. This course has given me valuable skills such as how to put together a management plan and has given practical experience working with a client and catering to their needs. These are skills I will need in my chosen profession and its wonderful to have learnt that from a class such as this.
This integrates a wide variety of skills and approaches, and applies them to the real world- something often very lacking with many other courses.

This is a key opportunity to apply what we have learned. I expected this class to be good, but I was surprised how much more solid some of my forestry and sampling skills have become. I'm much more at ease with the New England landscape, which was important to me.
i'm interested in creating management plans for forest conservation, so the course fit in well.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Great--I came to Yale wanting to develop a management plan for a protected area (though with an interest in doing it on a larger landscape scale, in the tropics). So it fit in perfectly with my interests, and was one of the best courses I took to prepare me for any future work in land management.
As my interests lie in land conservation, understanding how management plans result, and having the skill set to write management plans, will be a critical skill set.
This is an amazing theoretically synthetic and clinically practical course that gives training in how to think about land management.
Reputation, description, needed a capstone.

I wanted experience writing a management plan and presenting it to a real-world client. Management plans will form a central piece of my professional career and I am glad to have gotten this experience now.
Because of the practicallity of the information tought.
To acquire the skills stated above.
It came highly recomended. Also, I had seen the presentations last year and was impressed by what the class would produce.
How could I not take it? This is the most talked-up course, it seems.
it had a lot of hype, which was well-founed. also, i learned a variety of skills, and as mentioned above got better at GIS, excel, report writing, timber analysis, etc.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes! Great course.
Yes, the course has offered me a wonderful range of knowledge and experience that will continue to guide me into my professional career.
yes
Yes
Exceeded my expectations.
Yes.
Yes

Yes, absolutely. However, it was not quite as difficult as I expected. I worked on a team of two and I think this is easier than a team of 4.This is one of ( if not THE) best course that FES offers its students.
Yes, it did.
Yes it did
yes
Yes.
slightly below expectations, butstill recommended

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, reflecting on the amount of knowledge that I have gained over the course of this semester is amazing, and I feel much more knowledgeable about forest ecology, land management and land conservation.
not sure
Yes
Yes.
Yes, although unfortunately, since some tasks need to be divided up, I did less GIS than I had planned to.
Yes. I would have liked more instruction on1. wildlife2. data analysisbut i understand that this is a synthesis class and not so much of a lecture class.
Yes, I did.
Yes I did
yes
Yes.
no. we as a class glossed over the soils analysis component, and never really had the opportunity to go into more depth

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: breadth of interests and expertise. Mark did an excellent job, in my group, of bringing together people with a range of different talents that complemented each other nicely. Very happy with my group experience.

Group work is always a challenge, trying to mesh differing work styles, perspectives, and approaches. But that is just the nature of group work. And that too represents important skills to develop moving forward.

group work is tough. obviously great to be able to share the load, but i feel that so much of my energy went into communication with the group and into the meeting process (and the kinks that go with it). if you have a group over two people, you should appoint a project manager to set meeting times and divvy up tasks and be the point person so that communication does not become an issue.
Couldn't be done without group work
Working in a group is the only way this management plan would have been done. It would be a lot of work otherwise.

Advantages: made it possible to do the plan! Good experience working closely with someone else and dividing up tasks.Disadvantages: didn't get as much experience in certain skills, but that's ok and necessary.

My partner and I wrote the plan together. This exercise was one of the most valuable of the course. Working with someone else is rewarding and yet very trying as well and I learned a lot about myself and from my partner as well.

Working in a group on a long-term project can be stressful. It can be difficult to ensure that everyone has equal amounts of work, particularly given varying skillsets. But, this was a great lesson for the professional world.

I was in a very good group, so it was extremely beneficial to lower the work load. However, I could understand how the experience could be very negative if one didn't get along with their group member.

We complemented each other very well in skills but also in temperament. Mark astutely recognized different students' strengths and characters and created some amazingly resilient teams. Disadvantages - I managed to get away without learning much about some things I should know about (geology, herbaceous plants). However, I managed to strengthen other skills that are more important to me. So I'm happy with what I learned/practiced.
difficult to manage how to equally distribute work when there is just so much to go around

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Nothing much to offer - its going to be a ton of work, the work will start pretty much right from the start (or maybe by October) and it won't let up until the end of the semester (and actually, a lot of work will continue into January). Be ready for that, and be ready to commit a substantial amount of time to it.

see above. also, make sure you've taken silviculture and/or stands beforehand. talk with your classmates often about what you're observing and thinking about in the forest. get their take. pull from the expertise of as many people as you can, because you certainly won't know everything.
Work very hard at the beginning. Complete assignments as thoroughly as possible from the beginning. Spend a lot of time in the field
Keep ahead of your deadlines if you want to stay sane.
Have fun and don't be afraid to ask for help early and often.

1. Get ready to work hard- Professor Ashton has deadlines andexpects results.2. Do your fieldwork early- especially your title search- be prepared for MANY hours in the deed office.3. This is one of the best courses that FES offers- real world experience mixed with awesome, geeky, over-the-top analysis of a property.
Keep up on the deadlines

This is a very intense class but very enjoyable as well. For international students do not be intimidated about taking this class and donot worry about its applicability to your own situation back home. There are some core skills you learn that will be valuable to you no matter where you apply them.

Don't underestimate the time commitment. Don't sign up unless you intend to spend time on this class, otherwise your team will suffer. It's a great reason to spend many, many weekends outside in beautiful fall weather. Make sure each team has access to a car. Don't take too many other time-intensive classes.
take the course, but question mark on the need to take a whole weekend for everyone to visit all of the properties (you'll be plenty busy otherwise!)
